Chapter 1 Homework: AI-Assisted Coding and Exploratory Data Analysis

Instructions

This homework is meant to be completed with AI assistance (such as an in-browser LLM like ChatGPT, and/or using a CLI like Claude Code) to practice scaling your data exploration work.

For all questions, submit:

  1. Your code (in a .py file or Jupyter notebook)
  2. All visualizations generated
  3. Written answers to interpretation questions (can be in markdown or comments)
  4. The prompts you used with the AI assistant(s)

Dataset

You’ll be working with the California Housing Dataset, which contains information about California census block groups. You should load it using sklearn.datasets.fetch_california_housing and then create a Pandas DataFrame with the feature columns plus the target.

Data Set Characteristics:

  • Number of Instances: 20640
  • Number of Attributes: 8 numeric, predictive attributes and the target

Attribute Information:

  • MedInc: Median income in block group
  • HouseAge: Median house age in block group
  • AveRooms: Average number of rooms per household
  • AveBedrms: Average number of bedrooms per household
  • Population: Block group population
  • AveOccup: Average number of household members
  • Latitude: Block group latitude
  • Longitude: Block group longitude

Target Variable:

  • MedHouseVal: Median house value for California districts, expressed in hundreds of thousands of dollars ($100,000).

Notes:

  • This dataset comes from the StatLib repository: https://www.dcc.fc.up.pt/~ltorgo/Regression/cal_housing.html
  • This dataset was derived from the 1990 U.S. census and uses one row per census block group.
  • A block group typically has a population of 600 to 3,000 people.
  • Since rooms/bedrooms are averages per household, some values can be surprisingly large.
  • Missing Attribute Values: None

Use the following code to load the dataset into a DataFrame named df:

from sklearn.datasets import fetch_california_housing
import pandas as pd

housing = fetch_california_housing(as_frame=True)
df = housing.frame
df.head()
MedInc HouseAge AveRooms AveBedrms Population AveOccup Latitude Longitude MedHouseVal
0 8.3252 41.0 6.984127 1.023810 322.0 2.555556 37.88 -122.23 4.526
1 8.3014 21.0 6.238137 0.971880 2401.0 2.109842 37.86 -122.22 3.585
2 7.2574 52.0 8.288136 1.073446 496.0 2.802260 37.85 -122.24 3.521
3 5.6431 52.0 5.817352 1.073059 558.0 2.547945 37.85 -122.25 3.413
4 3.8462 52.0 6.281853 1.081081 565.0 2.181467 37.85 -122.25 3.422

Questions

Question 0:

  • Which LLM assistant(s) did you use? Be specific. For example, “I used ChatGPT in the browser”, or “I used Claude Code in the terminal”.

Question 1 (5 points)

Use AI to create a comprehensive data profile that includes:

  • Summary statistics for ALL numerical columns (including the target)
  • A report on missing values (which columns, how many, what percentage)
  • Identification of potential outliers in numerical columns (using percentile method: values below 1st or above 99th percentile)

Deliverables:

  • The prompt(s) you used
  • The code generated
  • The output/report

Question 2 (5 points)

Prompt the AI to create a function that generates a complete set of univariate visualizations for the dataset. This should include:

  • Histograms for all numerical columns (including the target)
  • All plots should be saved to a folder called univariate_plots/
  • Each plot should have proper labels and titles

Run the function and submit all generated plots along with your code.

Deliverables:

  • The prompt(s) you used
  • The code
  • All generated visualizations

Question 3 (5 points)

Use AI to create a pair plot (using sns.pairplot()) showing relationships between key numerical variables: MedHouseVal, MedInc, HouseAge, and AveRooms. Color the points by binned MedHouseVal (for example, low/medium/high using pd.qcut).

Based on the pair plot, answer:

  • Which pair of variables shows the strongest visual relationship?
  • Are there any variables that don’t seem to relate to MedHouseVal?
  • Do you notice any differences across the low/medium/high value groups?

Deliverables:

  • The prompt(s) you used
  • The pair plot visualization
  • Your written interpretation (3-4 sentences)

Question 4 (6 points)

Prompt the AI to create a function that compares MedHouseVal distributions across different subgroups. Specifically:

  • Compare MedHouseVal by binned MedInc (e.g., low/medium/high)
  • Compare MedHouseVal by binned HouseAge (e.g., 0-10, 10-30, 30+)
  • Compare MedHouseVal by latitude region (e.g., North/Central/South using cutoffs)
  • Generate both statistical summaries AND visualizations (box plots or violin plots)

Run this function and write 2-3 paragraphs interpreting the results. What insights did you gain about what drives housing values?

Deliverables:

  • The prompt(s) you used
  • The code
  • All visualizations
  • Your written interpretation

Question 5 (6 points)

Ask the AI to help you identify potential outliers in the MedHouseVal column. Your approach should:

  • Define outliers as values below the 1st percentile or above the 99th percentile
  • Create visualizations showing the distribution with outliers highlighted
  • Display summary statistics for the full dataset and for data excluding outliers
  • Investigate the outliers: are they data errors or legitimate expensive/cheap houses?

How many potential outliers did you identify? Should they be removed, or do they represent legitimate data points? Justify your answer.

Deliverables:

  • The prompt(s) you used
  • The code
  • Visualizations showing outliers
  • Written analysis (4-5 sentences)

Question 6 (6 points)

Use AI to create a comprehensive test suite for the housing dataset. Your test suite should include at least 5 unit tests that check:

  • Data types are correct
  • No negative values in columns where they don’t make sense (MedInc, AveRooms, AveBedrms, Population, AveOccup)
  • Reasonable ranges for geographic coordinates (Latitude between 32 and 42, Longitude between -125 and -114)
  • Reasonable ranges for HouseAge (e.g., 0 to 100)
  • No duplicate rows

Run all tests and report which (if any) failed.

Deliverables:

  • The prompt(s) you used
  • The complete test suite code
  • Test results

Question 7 (5 points)

Prompt the AI to create multiple scatter plots exploring the relationship between MedHouseVal and other numerical variables. You should generate:

  • MedHouseVal vs. MedInc (colored by Latitude)
  • MedHouseVal vs. HouseAge (colored by binned HouseAge)
  • MedHouseVal vs. AveRooms (with a trend line)
  • MedHouseVal vs. AveOccup (colored by Longitude)

For each plot, write 1-2 sentences describing what you observe.

Deliverables:

  • The prompt(s) you used
  • All scatter plots
  • Your written observations

Question 8 (6 points)

Use AI to create a function that systematically explores how MedHouseVal relates to engineered categorical variables created from numeric columns. For each engineered categorical variable, the function should:

  • Create a bar plot showing average MedHouseVal by category
  • Generate a box plot showing the distribution of MedHouseVal across categories
  • Calculate and display summary statistics (mean, median, count) for each category
  • Save all plots to a folder called categorical_analysis/

Use at least three engineered categories such as:

  • MedInc binned into low/medium/high
  • HouseAge binned into 3-4 groups
  • Latitude binned into North/Central/South

Run this function and write a paragraph identifying which engineered categories seem most important in determining house values.

Deliverables:

  • The prompt(s) you used
  • The function code
  • All generated visualizations
  • Your written analysis

Question 9 (6 points)

Use AI to create a function that performs a complete exploratory data analysis for ANY numerical column in the dataset. The function should:

  • Take a DataFrame and column name as inputs
  • Generate: histogram, box plot, and summary statistics
  • Identify potential outliers using percentiles (values below 1st or above 99th percentile)
  • Create a markdown-formatted report with findings
  • Save all plots to a specified folder

Run this function on three different columns: MedHouseVal, MedInc, and AveRooms.

Deliverables:

  • The prompt(s) you used
  • The function code
  • All generated visualizations
  • The markdown reports for each column

Question 10 (7 points)

For this final question, ask the AI to help you create a comprehensive EDA report. This should be a multi-page visualization that includes:

  • Overall dataset summary (rows, columns, missing values)
  • Distribution plots for key numerical variables
  • Correlation analysis
  • MedHouseVal analysis by different engineered categorical variables
  • Any interesting patterns or anomalies you discovered

Write a 1-page executive summary (300-400 words) that you would present to a stakeholder who doesn’t know anything about data science. Explain:

  • What the dataset contains
  • Key findings from your analysis
  • What factors seem most important in determining house values
  • Any data quality issues or limitations
  • Recommendations for next steps

Deliverables:

  • The prompt(s) you used
  • All visualizations in your EDA report
  • Your executive summary
  • Reflection: How did using AI change your approach to this comprehensive analysis compared to doing it by hand?

Submission Guidelines

Submit a ZIP file containing one folder for each problem. Within each folder you should have one file for each of the following:

  1. Code files: All .py files or Jupyter notebooks
  2. Visualizations folder: All plots and charts generated
  3. Written responses: A single document (PDF or Markdown) with all your written answers, interpretations, and AI prompts used
  4. Data: Include your cleaned/modified datasets if you created any
